Alibaba Group (BABA US & 9988 HK), China (Alex Yao) Building for Tomorrow: Clear Roadmap to Efficiency, Synergies, and Long- Term Value

Alibaba's JuneQ25 results strengthen our confidence in its mid- to long- term earnings outlook. We expect streamlined operations, strong financial resources, and clear strategies in quick commerce and cloud to drive sustainable double- digit earnings growth. While near- term profits face pressure from quick commerce investment, we believe efficiency gains and ecosystem synergies should support a stronger long- term trajectory. We cut our FY26 adj EPS by \(13\%\) and raise our FY27 adj EPS by \(6\%\) . Maintain OW with Jun- 26 PT of US\(170/HK\)165 on 12x CY2027E P/E.
Trip.com (TCOM US and 9961 HK), China (Alex Yao)

Well- positioned across time horizons: Cyclical momentum + structural growth TCOM has underperformed the sector average, as measured by KWEB, by 10ppts in the past three months, due to investor concerns about JD's potential entrance into the China domestic OTA market and a negative impact from a lackluster travel market during summer. We believe TCOM's solid 2Q25 result and healthy financial outlook for 3Q25 should dismiss investor concerns and drive share price upside. As a market leader in OTA with a strong foot print in mid to high- end consumers, TCOM looks well positioned to capture the following near- term and long- term trends: spillover effect from an A- share rally, outbound travel, international OTA expansion and inbound travel. Maintain OW with a new PT of US\(90/HK\)700 as we rollover our valuation base to 2026 with the same 20x target multiple.
Longfor Group (0960) (0960. HK, OW - HK\)10.58), China (Karl Chan)

For investors who want to play a medium- term turnaround story among non- SOE Chinese developers, we believe Longfor remains the best candidate with favourable risk- reward, because: 1) default risk is low with a comfortable balance sheet; 2) recurring net income of Rmb8- 9bn provides a solid buffer; 3) management remains one of the more capital- market- friendly ones (peers such as Vanke & Seazen no longer host result briefings, while Longfor not only hosts a results call, but also remains active in roadshows & conferences). Tactically, if there is significant policy easing in the housing market, we believe Longfor may offer \(>70\%\) upside if we simply benchmark to the peak in October 2024. However, even if we assume 'no big policy', we believe Longfor may still retrate gradually to \(\sim \mathsf{HK}\$ 14\) (33% potential upside) in the medium term, if we apply a 10x P/E to recurring (non- DP) net income (assuming zero value from DP). From a trading perspective, we also observe Longfor seems to have found a solid support level at \(\sim \mathsf{HK}\$ 9\) .
BYD - H&A, China (Nick Lai)

BYD's 2Q25 earnings came \(\mathsf{HK}30\%\) shy of expectations as a result of fierce price competition during the quarter that weighed on the GPM. A record- level price discount, seen in the entire industry in June has started to narrow after the government's "anti- involution" efforts. Management believes profitability should start to rebound in 3Q25. Longer term, our view on BYD remains unchanged, especially regarding its overseas expansion where capacity- build (i.e. Indonesia, Brazil, and Hungary) is one to two quarters ahead of plan. We thus forecast the overseas business to contribute to around half of BYD's total profit, up from \(\sim 40\%\) this year. We cut our 2025/26 estimates by \(21\% /7\%\) to reflect the results and thus reduce our Jun- 26 share price targets to \(\mathsf{HK}\$ 150 / \mathsf{Rmb}140\) .
Techntronic Industries (0669) (0669. HK, OW - HK\$100.40), China (Karen Li, CFA)

What a war chest of cash can achieve: TTI's investment in Japan- based Ryobi marks the first step, raising PT We are taking TTI off the Catalyst Watch as the stock has played out (+15% vs. HSI index \(+4\%\) since mid- July), in light of positive read- throughs from sales channels, US interest rate cut expectations, etc. Despite this, we stay bullish given the company's enhanced growth outlook. TTI's acquisition of a \(5.03\%\) stake in Japan's Ryobi (5851 JP; source: Bloomberg) reinforces its global brand ecosystems and aids the expansion into the Japanese market challenging the incumbent Makita. Additionally, positive read- throughs from Home Depot and Lowe's recently announced 2Q25 results, along with optimism for US interest rate cuts, tax reform and accelerating industrialization, bolster TTI's growth prospects amid the expanding global power tool TAM. With these developments, we are raising our PT to HK\$135, reflecting our confidence in TTI's ability to achieve robust earnings growth in the forecast period. Maintain OW.
See end pages for analyst certification. For important disclosures, please refer to the disclosure section at the end of the individual linked notes.

Building for Tomorrow: Clear Roadmap to Efficiency, Synergies, and Long- Term Value

Alibaba's JuneQ25 results strengthen our confidence in its mid- to long- term earnings outlook. We expect streamlined operations, strong financial resources, and clear strategies in quick commerce and cloud to drive sustainable double- digit earnings growth. While near- term profits face pressure from quick commerce investment, we believe efficiency gains and ecosystem synergies should support a stronger long- term trajectory. We cut our FY26 adj EPS by \(13\%\) and raise our FY27 adj EPS by \(6\%\) . Maintain OW with Jun- 26 PT of US \(170 / HK\) 165 on 12x CY2027E P/E.

- Investment returns should start to unfold over the next 12–24 months. We believe Alibaba's food delivery and quick commerce operations have reached scale that can drive efficiency gains, echoing Meituan's earlier path. With strong financial backing to sustain order and rider density, we expect unit economics to move beyond Ele.me's prior break-even ceiling in the long run and meaningfully narrow current losses in the next few quarters. Management's RMB1tn quick commerce GMV target within three years underscores the potential upside, in our view, while rising traffic should unlock additional monetization ahead of schedule, supporting CMR to outgrow China e-commerce GMV. We expect Alibaba to deliver sustained double-digit revenue growth (HSD CMR, \(20\% +\) cloud, mid-teens international) and faster profit growth as quick commerce losses narrow — with early signs possible by the Dec quarter, or at the latest by CY26.

- Quick Commerce: Scaling Synergies, Near-Term Earnings Pressure. Alibaba launched Taobao Instant Commerce in late April. Management noted the initiative is already generating material synergies — user engagement (+25% YoY Taobao MAUs in early Aug) and supply chain expansion (broader product offerings and front warehouse coverage beyond food). As the business scales, management is confident operating efficiency will improve quickly, driven by customer mix, order mix, and fulfillment optimization. Near-term unit economic losses remain significant, but management expects these losses to be halved in the short term.

Well- positioned across time horizons: Cyclical momentum + structural growth

TCOM has underperformed the sector average, as measured by KWEB, by 10ppts in the past three months, due to investor concerns about JD's potential entrance into the China domestic OTA market and a negative impact from a lackluster travel market during summer. We believe TCOM's solid 2Q25 result and healthy financial outlook for 3Q25 should dismiss investor concerns and drive share price upside. As a market leader in OTA with a strong foot print in mid to high- end consumers, TCOM looks well positioned to capture the following near- term and long- term trends: spillover effect from an A- share rally, outbound travel, international OTA expansion and inbound travel. Maintain OW with a new PT of US\\$90/HK\\$700 as we rollover our valuation base to 2026 with the same 20x target multiple.

- 2Q25 results review. TCOM's net revenue came in at Rmb14.8bn, up 16% yoy and 1% ahead of JPMc/consensus estimates. Adjusted OP was Rmb4.7bn, up 10% yoy and 5% ahead of JPMc. Adj. EPS came in at Rmb7.2, 6% below JPMc but 16% ahead of consensus estimates.

- Domestic travel with upside due to spillover effect from A-share rally: We expect domestic travel to grow at a MSD percentage in 3Q25, given management's comments on resilient domestic travel in the summer vacation. Additionally, we expect the recent A-share rally to partially boost consumer confidence and willingness due to a spillover effect, as rising asset value (in this case stock prices) could enhance consumers' perceived financial security, thereby leading to an increase in overall spending and possible growth in domestic travel demand. This offers upside potential to our domestic travel growth forecast.

- Strong momentum in inbound travel. International bookings on TCOM's platforms increased by over 60% yoy in 2Q25, indicating strong growth momentum. More specifically, inbound travel bookings more than doubled in 2Q, far outpacing the broader market's 30% yoy growth of inbound arrivals in 1H25. With 1) significantly eased visa policies in China, and 2) substantial market potential, as China's inbound tourism contributes to 0.5% of GDP vs. 1-5% of GDP for many other countries, according to management, we expect sustained momentum for inbound travel in short to mid-term.

Longing for a turnaround

For investors who want to play a medium- term turnaround story among non- SOE Chinese developers, we believe Longfor remains the best candidate with favourable risk- reward, because: 1) default risk is low with a comfortable balance sheet; 2) recurring net income of Rmb8- 9bn provides a solid buffer; 3) management remains one of the more capital- market- friendly ones (peers such as Vanke & Seazen no longer host result briefings, while Longfor not only hosts a results call, but also remains active in roadshows & conferences). Tactically, if there is significant policy easing in the housing market, we believe Longfor may offer \(>70\%\) upside if we simply benchmark to the peak in October 2024. However, even if we assume 'no big policy', we believe Longfor may still retare gradually to \(\sim \mathrm{HK}\) 14 (33% potential upside) in the medium term, if we apply a \(10x\mathrm{P / E}\) to recurring (non- DP) net income (assuming zero value from DP). From a trading perspective, we also observe Longfor seems to have found a solid support level at \(>HK\) 9.

A transformation in the making: Longfor's earlier strategy of actively building recurring income is paying off amid the current industry backdrop, as Longfor has been able to raise commercial property loans & long- term rental loans (latest balance: Rmb93bn), which have much longer tenure \((>10\) years) and lower financing costs \((3 - 4\%)\) to repay bonds. We estimate Longfor still has capacity to raise another Rmb10- 15bn, which can cover the outstanding balance of offshore bonds (Rmb9.5bn). Meanwhile, the Rmb8.0- 8.5bn FY25E net profit from recurring income (likely Rmb10bn in a few years' time) helps offset the earnings dilution from DP. Over the next few years, we expect Longfor to transform from a DP- focused developer into a recurring income- focused asset manager (Figure 6).

Admittedly, the drag from DP is not behind us: Longfor's 1H25 core net profit dropped \(71\%\) Y/Y (more in our First Take) due to gross development property (DP) margin dropping to only \(0.2\%\) (implying a net loss). From an earnings perspective, we think the worst is not over. We forecast FY25E core net profit to drop \(80\%\) Y/Y to Rmb1.4bn (implying almost no profit in 2H25E) (Figure 1), as the low- margin DP projects \((0 - 1\%\) gross margin) will still drag down overall earnings (we forecast recurring net profit to be Rmb8.0- 8.5bn in FY25E, implying a net loss of Rmb6.6- 7.1bn from DP). However, we expect earnings to rebound in FY26E and FY27E, and although the low- margin projects may remain dilutive (Figure 2), we believe the impact on overall earnings should start to ease.

Bottoming out after 2Q25 miss

BYD's 2Q25 earnings came in \(30\%\) shy of expectations as a result of fierce price competition during the quarter that weighed on the GPM. A record- level price discount seen in the entire industry in June has started to narrow after the government's "anti- involution" efforts. Management believes profitability should start to rebound in 3Q25. Longer term, our view on BYD remains unchanged, especially regarding its overseas expansion where capacity- build (i.e. Indonesia, Brazil, and Hungary) is one to two quarters ahead of plan. We thus forecast the overseas business to contribute to around half of BYD's total profit, up from \(\sim 40\%\) this year. We cut our 2025/26 estimates by \(21\% /7\%\) to reflect the results and thus reduce our Jun- 26 share price targets to \(\mathrm{HK}\$ 150 / \mathrm{Rmb}140\)

Recap of our thesis: We believe BYD will remain a competitive player in the global NEV market toward 2030 and beyond, thanks to: a) global expansion: We believe BYD's business model will strategically shift from a pure exporter in the past to increasing localization, along with completion and ramp- up of key overseas plants - Thailand (2H24), Indonesia (July 2025), Hungary (3Q25), Turkey and Brazil (1Q26). b) vertical integration and hence cost efficiencies; and c) comprehensive product offerings across price points and different powertrain variations - BEV and PHEV: we expect BYD's new models presumably with fresh design from 4Q25 onward will help boost sales volume into FY26- 27.

2Q25 result highlights: 1) Revenue grew by \(14\%\) yoy/ \(18\%\) qoq on the back of \(16\%\) yoy/ \(14\%\) qoq volume growth in 2Q25. 2) GPM dropped to \(16.3\%\) in 2Q25 from \(20.1\%\) in 1Q25, mainly due to fierce price competition starting in late May. 3) BYD- E's contribution: earnings at BYD- E were up by \(22\%\) yoy/ \(78\%\) qoq. 4) Opex ratio narrowed from \(12.9\%\) in 1Q25 to \(12.1\%\) in 2Q25 mainly thanks to well- contained SG&A expenses while R&D expenses increased dramatically by \(71\% \text{yoy}\) or \(8\% \text{qoq}\) in 2Q25 due to company's continued investment in core technologies. Overall, the company's net earnings were down \(30\%\) yoy and net profit per unit dropped to Rmb 5.6k. We project quarterly per unit profit will improve into 2H25 thanks to narrowing pricing discounts.

What a war chest of cash can achieve: TTI's investment in Japan- based Ryobi marks the first step, raising PT

We are taking TTI off the Catalyst Watch as the stock has played out \((+15\%)\) vs. HSI index \(+4\%\) since mid- July), in light of positive read- throughs from sales channels, US interest rate cut expectations, etc. Despite this, we stay bullish given the company's enhanced growth outlook. TTI's acquisition of a \(5.03\%\) stake in Japan's Ryobi (5851 JP; source: Bloomberg) reinforces its global brand ecosystems and aids the expansion into the Japanese market challenging the incumbent Makita. Additionally, positive read- throughs from Home Depot and Lowe's recently announced 2Q25 results, along with optimism for US interest rate cuts, tax reform and accelerating industrialization, bolster TTI's growth prospects amid the expanding global power tool TAM. With these developments, we are raising our PT to HK\$135, reflecting our confidence in TTI's ability to achieve robust earnings growth in the forecast period. Maintain OW.

- Strategic investment in Ryobi enhances its global brand and market expansion. TTI's acquisition of a \(5.03\%\) stake in Ryobi is a strategic move that bolsters its global brand ecosystem and facilitates market expansion into Japan, challenging Makita's presence. This investment aligns with TTI's vision to establish itself as a leading "Own Brand Manufacturer" (OBM) in the industrial tools sector, highlighting the benefits of TTI's earlier working capital normalization and deleveraging. The utilization of its war-chest cash positions it ahead of competitors like Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) which remains highly levered.

- Home Depot and Lowe's results underscore TTI's demand outlook with pricing power and DIY improvement. The 2Q25 results from Home Depot and Lowe's highlight key messages of pricing power and DIY improvement. Home Depot, a strategic partner and key customer for TTI, demonstrated disciplined pricing strategies with mild price hikes, reflecting strong market positioning. Both retailers reported robust demand in Pro and DIY segments, suggesting a favorable market environment for TTI. Home Depot's disciplined pricing strategy and Lowe's strategic expansion into Pro channels indicate a consolidated market landscape, offering positive read-throughs for TTI's demand outlook. These insights reinforce TTI's strategic alignment with leading home improvement retailers, enhancing its market presence and growth prospects.

- The power tool industry is benefiting from strong pricing power, efficient supply chain adjustments, and rising rate cut optimism. Our review of 2Q25 performances revealed better-than-expected earnings and favorable margin trends despite disruptions. The swift shift to overseas manufacturing bases has enhanced operational efficiency, with expanding operating scale and local procurement chains. The impending US rate cuts, regardless of the pace, along with tax reform, could further boost power tool demand, in our view.
Price Target (Dec- 26): HK\$135.00 Prior (Dec- 26): HK\$129.00
